DataElement.preferredName: Esophagus and Esophagogastric Junction Adenocarcinoma AJCC Edition 8 Pathologic Distant Metastasis M Category
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Extent of the distant metastasis for esophageal and esophagogastric junction adenocarcinoma based on clinical stage information combined with operative findings, and evidence obtained from pathology review when surgery is the first definitive therapy, using AJCC Ed. 8 criteria.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A malignant tumor with glandular differentiation arising predominantly from Barrett mucosa in the lower third of the esophagus.  Rare examples of esophageal adenocarcinoma deriving from ectopic gastric mucosa in the upper esophagus have also been reported.  Grossly, esophageal adenocarcinomas are similar to esophageal squamous cell carcinomas.  Microscopically, adenocarcinomas arising in the setting of Barrett esophagus are typically papillary and/or tubular.  The prognosis is poor._Caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology._One criteria of the TNM staging system. M refers to the presence of metastasis.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A malignant tumor with glandular differentiation arising predominantly from Barrett mucosa in the lower third of the esophagus.  Rare examples of esophageal adenocarcinoma deriving from ectopic gastric mucosa in the upper esophagus have also been reported.  Grossly, esophageal adenocarcinomas are similar to esophageal squamous cell carcinomas.  Microscopically, adenocarcinomas arising in the setting of Barrett esophagus are typically papillary and/or tubular.  The prognosis is poor.

Concepts.definition: A malignant tumor with glandular differentiation arising predominantly from Barrett mucosa in the lower third of the esophagus.  Rare examples of esophageal adenocarcinoma deriving from ectopic gastric mucosa in the upper esophagus have also been reported.  Grossly, esophageal adenocarcinomas are similar to esophageal squamous cell carcinomas.  Microscopically, adenocarcinomas arising in the setting of Barrett esophagus are typically papillary and/or tubular.  The prognosis is poor.

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 10-4-18 Changed from Draft New to Released/tmt. 9-24-18 tt created for standardization.

ValueDomain.preferredName: Esophagus and Esophagogastric Junction Carcinoma American Joint Committee on Cancer Edition 8 M Category
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A finding about one or more characteristics of esophagus and esophagogastric junction cancer, following the rules of the TNM AJCC v8 classification system. This staging system applies to carcinomas including squamous cell carcinoma, adenocarcinoma, adenosquamous carcinoma, undifferentiated carcinoma, neuroendocrine cancers, and adenocarcinoma with neuroendocrine features. Sarcomas, nonepithelial cancers, and gastrointestinal stromal tumors are not staged using this staging system. (from AJCC 8th Ed.)_One criteria of the TNM staging system. M refers to the presence of metastasis._A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.
